scoop.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: an important or exciting news story that is printed in one newspaper or shown on one television station before any of the others know about it
scoop.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: a journalist looking for a scoop
scoop.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a round deep spoon for serving food, for example ice cream or mashed potato
scoop.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: an amount of food served with a scoop
scoop.translation[0].definitions[3].note: whatâ€™s the scoop? (=used to ask for information or news)
scoop.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: the inside scoop  (=special information that other people do not have) on the markets
scoop.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to pick something up or remove it using a scoop or a spoon, or your curved hand
scoop.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: She bent down and scooped up the little dog.
Cut the tomato in half and scoop out the seeds with a teaspoon.
scoop.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to be the first newspaper to print an important news report
scoop.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Time and again, we have scooped our rivals.
scoop.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to win a prize or award
scoop.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Britain scooped the top prize in the over-50s category.
